spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The phoenix's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 24}). The phoenix can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Divine Initiative
entries: The phoenix always acts on initiative count 19 (losing ties).

trait.name: Illumination
entries: The phoenix sheds bright light in a 60-foot radius and dim light for an additional 60 feet.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the phoenix fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The phoenix has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Radiant Armor
entries: The phoenix adds its Charisma modifier to its AC.

trait.name: Undying Flames (3/Day)
entries: While the phoenix is at 0 hit points, roll a {@dice d6} at the end of each of its turns. On a 6, its remains begin to swirl in a violent firestorm as it is reborn with half its hit point maximum. Any creature within 60 feet of it when it is reborn must make a {@dc 22} Dexterity saving throw, taking 44 ({@damage 8d10}) radiant damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one. The explosion ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried. The phoenix cannot resurrect in this manner if its remains are destroyed by being doused with water, or if they are in an area affected by the hallow spell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The phoenix uses its holy radiance. It then makes three attacks: one with its beak and two with its radiant talons.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 15} to hit, reach 10ft., one target. {@h}29 ({@damage 4d10 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Radiant Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 15} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 3d10 + 7}) slashing damage and 18 ({@damage 4d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Heavenly Fires {@recharge}
entries: The phoenix calls down wave of fiery hot air in a 60-foot line that is 15 feet wide, originating at a point of its choosing within 60 feet of it. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 24} Constitution saving throw, taking 90 ({@damage 20d8}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

action.name: Holy Radiance
entries: Each creature of the phoenix' choice that is within 120 feet of the phoenix and can see it must succeed on a {@dc 24} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition blinded} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creatures saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the phoenix' Holy Radiance for the next 24 hours.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The phoenix makes an attack with its radiant talons.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The phoenix makes a Wisdom (perception) check.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The phoenix beats its wings. Each creature within 15 feet of the phoenix must succeed a {@dc 24} Dexterity saving throw or take 21 ({@damage 4d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. The phoenix can then fly up to half its flying speed.

Over the millennia, the Shijin have created great creatures in their own image. These creatures are almost as revered as the Shijin themselves, as they act as proxies for the Shijin they serve. They are known as the Serafs; guardians of virtue and the circle of life. Orochi is the exception here, as she has not created any creatures in her own image. She has, however, created serpentine creatures to help her rid the Orient of undead.

entries.name: Serafs of Suzako
entries: The phoenixes posses Suzaku's ability to reincarnate. They act as her agents in all matters and answer only to her. They are kind creatures, though they prefer to stay out of the affairs of the mortal races.

entries.name: Immortal Nature
entries: Suzaku's Serafs don't require food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Great Phoenix
entries: These Serafs are massive in stature. Unlike Suzaku, they are made of flesh and blood, though they are surrounded by pure radiant energy. Much like Suzaku, they act as arbiters of good wherever they go. From them descend the regular phoenixes, as well as the lesser phoenixes.

entries.name: Phoenix
entries: Unlike their larger and more powerful kin, the regular phoenixes are made purely of flesh and blood, though a trail of light follows them when they fly.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The phoenix's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}). The phoenix can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Divine Initiative
entries: The phoenix always acts on initiative count 18 (losing ties).

trait.name: Illumination
entries: The phoenix sheds bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If the phoenix fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The phoenix has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Radiant Armor
entries: The phoenix adds its Charisma modifier to its AC.

trait.name: Undying Flames (1/Day)
entries: While the phoenix is at 0 hit points, roll a {@dice d6} at the end of each of its turns. On a 6, its remains begin to swirl in a violent firestorm as it is reborn with half its hit point maximum. Any creature within 60 feet of it when it is reborn must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) radiant damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one. The explosion ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried. The phoenix cannot resurrect in this manner if its remains are destroyed by being doused with water, or if they are in an area affected by the hallow spell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The great phoenix uses its holy radiance. It then makes three attacks: one with its beak and two with its radiant talons.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d10 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Radiant Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) slashing damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Holy Radiance
entries: Each creature of the phoenix' choice that is within 60 feet of the phoenix and can see it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition blinded} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creatures saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the phoenix' Holy Radiance for the next 24 hours.

Over the millennia, the Shijin have created great creatures in their own image. These creatures are almost as revered as the Shijin themselves, as they act as proxies for the Shijin they serve. They are known as the Serafs; guardians of virtue and the circle of life. Orochi is the exception here, as she has not created any creatures in her own image. She has, however, created serpentine creatures to help her rid the Orient of undead.

entries.name: Serafs of Suzako
entries: The phoenixes posses Suzaku's ability to reincarnate. They act as her agents in all matters and answer only to her. They are kind creatures, though they prefer to stay out of the affairs of the mortal races.

entries.name: Immortal Nature
entries: Suzaku's Serafs don't require food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Great Phoenix
entries: These Serafs are massive in stature. Unlike Suzaku, they are made of flesh and blood, though they are surrounded by pure radiant energy. Much like Suzaku, they act as arbiters of good wherever they go. From them descend the regular phoenixes, as well as the lesser phoenixes.

entries.name: Phoenix
entries: Unlike their larger and more powerful kin, the regular phoenixes are made purely of flesh and blood, though a trail of light follows them when they fly.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Kirin's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 26}, spell attack +18). Kirin can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Creature Sense
entries: While within a forest, Kirin is aware of the presence of any other creatures in the forest. He knows the distance and direction to each creature, as well as its alignment, but can't sense anything else about it. A creature protected by a mind blank spell, a nondetection spell, or similar magic can't be perceived in this manner.

trait.name: Discorporation
entries: When Kirin drops to 0 hit points or dies, his body is destroyed but his essence travels back to Tengoku, and he is unable to take physical form for a time.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Kirin fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Limited Magic Immunity
entries: Unless he wishes to be affected, Kirin is immune to spells of 6th level or lower. He has advantage against all other spells and magical effects.

trait.name: Ensorcelled Woods
entries: Kirin can speak through any plant within 5 miles of him. If he's in a forest, he can speak from every plant in the forest, including with his telepathy.

trait.name: One With The Forest
entries: Within a forest Kirin leaves no evidence of his passing and tracking him is impossible even by magical means. In addition, he ignores movement impediments and damage from plans unless they are creatures, allowing him to move through any area of vegetation without squeezing, regardless of how much room there is.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If Kirin moves at least 10 feet straight toward a creature right before hitting it with a claw attack, the target must succeed on a {@dc 23} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, Kirin can take a bonus action to make one bite attack against it.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: Kirin regenerates 20 hit points at the start of his turn.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: Kirin can use his action to polymorph into a Medium, Large, or Huge white tiger or back into his true form. His statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment he is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. He reverts to his true form if he dies.

trait.name: Sylvan Phasing
entries: Roll a {@dice d20} at the start of each of Kirin's turns. On a roll of 16 or higher, Kirin becomes translucent until the start of his next turn. For the duration, Kirin is immune to all damage and can move through other creatures and objects, but he can't attack with his bite or claws. He is ejected to the nearest empty space if he ends his turn inside an object.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Kirin uses his Thorn Vines ability and makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 15} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}29 ({@damage 4d10 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 15} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 4d8 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Thorn Vines
entries: Kirin magically causes razor sharp vines to burst from the ground at a point within 120 feet that he can see. Each creature of Kirin's choice within 20 feet of that point, must make a {@dc 22} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 22}). Until the grapple ends, the target is held 10 ft. above the ground, is {@condition restrained}, and has disadvantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
Each vine can be attacked (AC 18; 10 hit points; immunity to poison and psychic damage). A vine can also be broken if a creature takes an action and succeeds on a {@dc 22} Strength check against it.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: Kirin makes one attack with his Bite, Claw, Slam, or Thorn Vines.

legendary.name: Cast Spell (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Kirin casts a spell.

legendary.name: Move
entries: Kirin moves up to his speed.

legendary.name: Vine Storm (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: Kirin magically causes razor sharp vines to burst from the ground. Each creature of Kirin's choice within 60 feet of him that touches the ground, must make a {@dc 22} Dexterity saving throw. A creature becomes {@condition poisoned} and takes 45 ({@damage 10d8}) piercing damage plus 45 ({@damage 10d8}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage and doesn't become {@condition poisoned} on a successful one. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, a creature is also {@condition unconscious} while {@condition poisoned} in this way. The target wakes up if it takes damage, or if another creature takes an action to shake it awake.

At the heart of Oriental faith are five spiritual creatures, each guarding a direction on the compass as well as the center. Each Shijin has a corresponding season, color, element, virtue, and other traits which connect them with the daily routines of the mortal races. An earth wu jen, for example, would draw on the domain of Kirin, while a water shugenja would prey to Genbu, and a warlock with a Great Phoenix patron might get her powers from one of the Great Phoenixes or even Suzaku herself.

Genbu, Kirin, Suzaku, and Ryu all have their own holiday in the Orient, where they and their corresponding virtues are celebrated. Noticeably, Orochi doesn't have a holiday, as she is considered at the center of everything.
The Shijin answer to the Jade Emperor alone — the spirit of the First Emperor who united the Clans.

entries.name: Serafs
entries: Over the millennia, the Shijin have created great creatures in their own image. These creatures are almost as revered as the Shijin themselves, as they act as proxies for the Shijin they serve. They are known as the Serafs; guardians of virtue and the circle of life. Orochi is the exception here, as she has not created any creatures in her own image. She has, however, created serpentine creatures to help her rid the Orient of the undead.

entries.name: Kirin
entries: Kirin is also known as The White Tiger, Great Guardian of the South, Aspect of Earth, Lord of Spring, The Great Pacifist, and Father of Righteousness. Kirin could very well be the first fey (or at least among them).

Kirin is a gigantic creature, resembling an enormous white tiger. He has three long beards and a white mane that runs down his back. Massive spikes protrude from his shoulders and he has glowing, green eyes on his friendly face. He is so in touch with the natural forces of the world that the forest of the Orient are but an extension of himself.
He is a good-hearted creature, seeking to restrain, rather than harm evildoers.

He is also considered a protector and preserver. Three days after the burial of a good and honorable lord, daimyo, or Emperor, the top-most earth lifts from the grave and forms a crouching tiger on the grave. This is Kirin bestowing his blessings upon the deceased. In rare cases, during times of great peril, Kirin might even resurrect such an honorable leader on the third day.

entries.name: Immortal Nature
entries: Kirin doesn't require food, drink, or sleep.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (3/Day)
headerEntries: Orochi can innately cast {@spell earthquake} and {@spell tsunami} (spell save {@dc 26}). Her spellcasting ability is Charisma.

trait.name: Discorporation
entries: When Orochi drops to 0 hit points or dies, her body is destroyed but her essence travels back to Diyu, and she is unable to take physical form for a time.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: Orochi is immune to any spell or effect that would alter her form.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Orochi fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Limited Magic Immunity
entries: Unless she wishes to be affected, Orochi is immune to spells of 6th level or lower. She has advantage against all other spells and magical effects.

trait.name: Multiple Heads
entries: Orochi can take one reaction per turn, rather than only one per round. She also has advantage against being knocked {@condition unconscious}. If she fails a saving throw against an effect that would stun a creature, one of her unspent legendary actions is spent.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: Orochi regenerates 30 hit points at the start of its turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Orochi instantly casts {@spell earthquake} if it is on land or {@spell tsunami} if it is in water. It then makes three attacks: two with its claws and one with its tail.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}24 ({@damage 4d6 + 10}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 25 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d8 + 10}) piercing damage plus.

Orochi's options are associated with her eight heads (a bite and a magical effect for each). Once Orochi chooses a legendary action option for one of her heads, she can't choose another one associated with that head until the start of her next turn.

legendary.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}32 ({@damage 4d10 + 10}) slashing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) cold damage (blue-eyed head), fire damage (fiery-eyed head), lightning damage (crackling-eyed head), necrotic damage (black-eyed head), poison damage (snake-eyed head), psychic damage (eyeless head, void-eyed head), or radiant damage (white-eyed head).

legendary.name: Blue-Eyed Head: Frost Breath (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Orochi breathes an icy blast in a 90-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 26} Dexterity saving throw, taking 72 ({@damage 16d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendary.name: Black-Eyed Head: Death Breath (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Orochi breathes a necrotic blast in a 90-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 26} Constitution saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If a creature fails its saving throw by 5 or more, its hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken and Orochi gains temporary hit points equal to that amount.

legendary.name: Crackling-Eyed Head: Chain Lightning (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Orochi shoots a bolt of crackling lightning that arcs toward a creature within 150 feet that Orochi can see. Three bolts then leap from that target to as many as three other targets, each of which must be within 30 feet of the first target. A target can be a creature or an object and can be targeted by only one of the bolts. The first target must make a {@dc 26} Dexterity saving throw, taking 90 ({@damage 20d8}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. All other targets must succeed a {@dc 26} Dexterity saving throw, taking 45 ({@damage 10d8}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendary.name: Eyeless Head: Mind-Shattering Realities (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Orochi targets a creature within 100 feet that she can see, forcefully connecting its psyche to otherworldly realities of mind-shattering proportions within the vastness of space. The target takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) psychic damage and must make a {@dc 26} Wisdom saving throw.

On a failed save, the creature's Intelligence and Charisma scores become 1 for up to 24 hours. The target can't cast spells, activate magic items, understand language, or communicate in any intelligible way. The target can, however, identify its friends, follow them, and even protect them.

The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a successful save. A {@spell remove curse}, {@spell greater restoration}, or {@spell wish} spell also ends the effect early.

legendary.name: Fiery-Eyed Head: Magma Spit (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Orochi spews a giant glob of molten stone and metal, targeting a point within 150 feet that she can see. Each creature in a 30-foot-radius centered on that point must make a {@dc 26} Dexterity saving throw, taking 35 ({@damage 10d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The magma and its heat damages objects in the area and ignites flammable objects that aren't being worn or carried. Plant life in the area dies. The area remains filled with magma for up to 5 rounds, and when a creature enters the area for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there, the creature takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) fire damage.

legendary.name: Snake-Eyed Head: Mesmerizing Stare (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Orochi's snake-eyed head targets a creature within 50 feet that can see her and telepathically commands it to carry out some service or refrain from some action or course of activity. The target must succeed a {@dc 26} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition charmed} by Orochi for up to 1 minute. While the creature is {@condition charmed} by Orochi, it takes 27 ({@damage 5d10}) psychic damage each time it acts in a manner directly counter to Orochi's instructions.
Orochi can issue any command she chooses, short of an activity that would result in certain death. Should Orochi issue a suicidal command, the charm ends.
Orochi can end the effect early by using an action to dismiss it. A {@spell remove curse}, {@spell greater restoration}, or {@spell wish} spell also ends it.

legendary.name: Void-Eyed Head (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Orochi targets a creature within 20 feet that she can see. The target must succeed a {@dc 26} Charisma saving throw or have its mind drift into the infinite void for 24 hours. For the duration the target has disadvantage on attack rolls and must make a {@dc 20} Charisma saving throw at the start of each of its turns. If it fails, it wastes its action that turn doing nothing as its mind is drifting among the stars within the infinite blackness. If it fails its saving throw by 5 or more, it also gains an indefinite madness as found in the Dungeon Master's Guide. If it fails its saving throw by 10 or more, it instead gains a short-term madness.

The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a successful save. A {@spell remove curse}, {@spell greater restoration}, or {@spell wish} spell also ends the effect early.

legendary.name: White-Eyed Head: Banishing Blast (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Ranged Spell Attack: {@hit 18} to hit, range 150/300 ft., one target. {@h}55 ({@damage 10d10}) force damage. If this attack reduces the target to 50 hit points or fewer, it is banished. If the target is native to a different plane of existence than the one it is on, the target disappears, returning to its home plane.

If the target is native to the plane it is on, the creature vanishes into a harmless demiplane. While there, the target is {@condition incapacitated}. It remains there for up to 1 minute, at which point the target reappears in the space it left or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied. The target can make a {@dc 26} Intelligence saving throw at the end of each of its turns, escaping the demiplane early on a success.
Undead have disadvantage on the saving throw, and on a failed save they are destroyed, so long as their CR is lower than Orochi's.

At the heart of Oriental faith are five spiritual creatures, each guarding a direction on the compass as well as the center. Each Shijin has a corresponding season, color, element, virtue, and other traits which connect them with the daily routines of the mortal races. An earth wu jen, for example, would draw on the domain of Kirin, while a water shugenja would prey to Genbu, and a warlock with a Great Phoenix patron might get her powers from one of the Great Phoenixes or even Suzaku herself.

Genbu, Kirin, Suzaku, and Ryu all have their own holiday in the Orient, where they and their corresponding virtues are celebrated. Noticeably, Orochi doesn't have a holiday, as she is considered at the center of everything.
The Shijin answer to the Jade Emperor alone — the spirit of the First Emperor who united the Clans.

entries.name: Serafs
entries: Over the millennia, the Shijin have created great creatures in their own image. These creatures are almost as revered as the Shijin themselves, as they act as proxies for the Shijin they serve. They are known as the Serafs; guardians of virtue and the circle of life. Orochi is the exception here, as she has not created any creatures in her own image. She has, however, created serpentine creatures to help her rid the Orient of the undead.

entries.name: Orochi
entries: Orochi is also known as The Eight-Headed Serpent, The Inevitable, Aspect of Metal and Void, Lady of Death, and Mother of Fate. Orochi wants to protect the cycle of life, doing so at any cost. She doesn't have morality like the other Shijin, and she values neither consciousness nor life in the traditional sense. As long as new life keeps springing into existence and keeps dying, Orochi is content. A single life means nothing to her, though she has a burning hatred for undead creatures, which she sees as a mockery of life itself. Orochi doesn't need drink, food or sleep.
Orochi has eight heads, each representing one of her powers. Each head can be described as follows:

entries.name: Blue-Eyed Head
entries: This head has sparkling, blue eyes that radiate an immense chill. The head represents Orochi's mercilessness and allows her to freeze others in their tracks.

entries.name: Black-Eyed Head
entries: This head has dead, black eyes. The head represents Orochi's mastery of death and allows her to call upon the full might of Diyu.

entries.name: Crackling-Eyed Head
entries: This head has eyes that crackle with lightning. The head represents Orochi's unwillingness to compromise and allows her to punish transgressors with the power of lightning.

entries.name: Eyeless Head
entries: This head has empty eye sockets. The head represents Orochi's immense, unfathomable understanding of the inner workings of the universe and allows her ravish the minds of others.

entries.name: Fiery-Eyed Head
entries: This head has eyes that burn with eternal flames. The head represents Orochi's wrath and enables her to spit molten hot magma.

entries.name: Snake-Eyed Head
entries: This head has mesmerizing, snake-like eyes. The head represents Orochi's dominance. It allows her to command others to do her bidding.

entries.name: Void-Eyed Head
entries: This head has eyes that bend reality within them, seemingly non-existent, yet portraying stars and galaxies within an infinite blackness in their place. The head represents Orochi's connection with eternity and fate. It allows Orochi to stop other creatures in their tracks by showing them the meaning of infinity.

entries.name: White-Eyed Head
entries: This head has completely white eyes that radiate a holy glow. The head represents Orochi's power over death and ensuring things are as they are supposed to be. This head allows Orochi to banish creatures and to destroy undead.

entries.name: Immortal Nature
entries: Orochi doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Orochi's Lair
entries: Orochi's makes her lair in Youdu, a vast city pervaded in perpetual darkness. Within the city live countless spirits awaiting rebirth, each of them like children as they have forgotten their former lives completely and are unable to form new memories while in the city.

entries.name: Outside Time and Space
entries: Any creature that finds itself within Diyu has a physical body, though it isn't the creature's actual physical body. Instead, a creature only exists as its consciousness – its soul – while its body within Diyu is a representative manifestation of itself. Usually, those that find themselves here are dead and have left their actual bodies behind for good.

If somebody should find a way here without dying, a creature's body and soul are still separated, the body left behind before entering Diyu. No creature apart from Orochi and her Serafs can have physical bodies within Diyu. Any harm done to a creature's "body" isn't real, though the pain feels real in all respects. Except by Orochi's hand, such creatures cannot die, however, as their consciousnesses are everlasting while in Diyu. Furthermore, time moves differently within Orochi's layer sometimes faster, sometimes slower all according to Orochi's will.
Contrary to the other Shijin, Orochi's home isn't a layer of Tengoku. Diyu is a layer outside of time and space, located within the Void itself.

entries.name: Youdu and The Ten Courts
entries: Youdu is located in the heart of Diyu and is surrounded by The Ten Courts, each located on an inner layer within Diyu. Each court is presided over by a {@creature court king of Diyu|MotO}; a celestial entity of great power. Each king commands the very court itself as well as numerous umbral and void serpents. When a court king decides that a creature has suffered enough for its crimes, he sends it back to King Quinguang where it might be judged again for other crimes committed.

{@b Hantei, The First Court.} The First Court is presided over by King Quinguang and entry to the entirety of Diyu. A trial is held for those that arrive here. They are judged based on their deeds in life. Those who have had virtuous lives are sent to the Fires of Life where Suzaku reincarnates them. Those whose past deeds outweigh their crimes are sent to Men-Po Pavilion, The Tenth Court. Those whose crimes outweigh their good deeds, are sent to the Mirror of Retribution.

The Mirror of Retribution reveals purest truth. A creature that sees itself in the mirror, sees its true self and all the deeds it has ever done to others are inflicted upon the mirror's reflection. Depending on the severities of a creatures actions, the DM might ask for one or more Charisma saving throws or gain a form of madness as described in the Dungeon Master's Guide. Based on what the mirror reveals, King Quinguang sentences a creature to one of the other courts.

items: {@b Arbuda, The Second Court.} Gamblers, prostitutes, thieves, and those who have inflicted physical injury to others are sent here for punishment. King Chujiang presides here, giving offenders a punishment reflective of their crimes. His punishments include perpetual burning in a fiery pit, being frozen to the core, or perpetual drowning in a pool of blood.

{@b Nirarbuda, The Third Court.} Those sent here are guilty of ungratefulness, disrespecting their elders, or raiding tombs. King Songdi's punishment always includes cutting a creature's heart out, but the particularly vicious wrongdoers are also tied to a glowing hot copper pillar.

{@b Atata, The Fourth Court.} If a creature is guilty economic fraud or cheating, it is sent to Atata. King Wuguan judges those sent here to either be bound and continuously pounded by a large stone mallet or be restrained within a large mortar while a massive pestle grinds them.

{@b Hahava, The Fifth Court.} This court is for those that have plotted another's death to obtain their property and for money lenders that charged exorbitant rates. King Yanluo lets transgressors tumble down a never-ending slope of the sharpest blades.

{@b Huhuva, The Sixth Court.} Cheaters and kidnappers are sent here, along with those that objectify others, or waste food. A visit to The Sixth Court entails being slowly sawn into two from groin to head by King Piencheng, only to be glued back together before starting over.

{@b Utpala, The Seventh Court.} Those who have committed psychological abuse or thrived on sowing rumors about others. King Taishan pulls out the tongues of his visitors before trapping them in a wok of boiling oil.
{@b Padma, The Eighth Court.} The Eighth Court is the destination for those that have brought dishonor or shame to their family. King Dushi pulls out their intestines and dismembers their bodies.

{@b Avici, The Ninth Court.} Only the worst of the worst are sent to Avici. Rapists, murderers, and those that had the means to stop such atrocities but didn't are among those found here. While those sentenced to another court are always released at some point, most of the souls trapped here are never released. The court is presided over by King Pingdeng. Each prisoner is dismembered and crushed for all eternity.

{@b Men-Po Pavilion, The Tenth Court.} Those that find themselves in The Tenth Court have either lived a decent life or been thoroughly punished for their crimes. King Zhuanlun presides over this domain but doesn't actually pass any judgment. Instead he offers each newcomer a cup of magical tea the Tea of Forgetfulness. It permanently clears a consciousness of all past memories, and even a wish spell can only restore fractions of those memories. Only Orochi herself can ever truly return all memories that have been lost in this way. A visitor must drink the tea before being capable of entering Youdu. Men-Po Pavilion is full of visitors who refuse to drink the tea for various reasons.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (At Will)
headerEntries: The court king can innately cast {@spell wall of force} and {@spell zone of truth} (spell save {@dc 22}). Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom.

trait.name: Bound
entries: The court king is bound to its court, unable to ever leave its confines.

trait.name: Discorporation
entries: When the court king drops to 0 hit points or dies, its body is destroyed but its essence remains. It is able to take physical form again after 1 minute, appearing in a location of its choosing within its court.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The court king has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Punish
entries: {@atk ms,rs} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 150/300 ft., up to six creatures that the court king can see. {@h}32 ({@damage 4d12 + 6}) psychic damage and the target is {@condition paralyzed}. The target can make a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a successful save.

entries.name: Youdu and The Ten Courts
entries: Youdu is located in the heart of Diyu, the Lair of {@creature Orochi|MotO} and is surrounded by The Ten Courts, each located on an inner layer within Diyu. Each court is presided over by a {@b court king of Diyu}; a celestial entity of great power. Each king commands the very court itself as well as numerous umbral and void serpents. When a court king decides that a creature has suffered enough for its crimes, he sends it back to King Quinguang where it might be judged again for other crimes committed.

{@b Hantei, The First Court.} The First Court is presided over by King Quinguang and entry to the entirety of Diyu. A trial is held for those that arrive here. They are judged based on their deeds in life. Those who have had virtuous lives are sent to the Fires of Life where Suzaku reincarnates them. Those whose past deeds outweigh their crimes are sent to Men-Po Pavilion, The Tenth Court. Those whose crimes outweigh their good deeds, are sent to the Mirror of Retribution.

The Mirror of Retribution reveals purest truth. A creature that sees itself in the mirror, sees its true self and all the deeds it has ever done to others are inflicted upon the mirror's reflection. Depending on the severities of a creatures actions, the DM might ask for one or more Charisma saving throws or gain a form of madness as described in the Dungeon Master's Guide. Based on what the mirror reveals, King Quinguang sentences a creature to one of the other courts.

items: {@b Arbuda, The Second Court.} Gamblers, prostitutes, thieves, and those who have inflicted physical injury to others are sent here for punishment. King Chujiang presides here, giving offenders a punishment reflective of their crimes. His punishments include perpetual burning in a fiery pit, being frozen to the core, or perpetual drowning in a pool of blood.

{@b Nirarbuda, The Third Court.} Those sent here are guilty of ungratefulness, disrespecting their elders, or raiding tombs. King Songdi's punishment always includes cutting a creature's heart out, but the particularly vicious wrongdoers are also tied to a glowing hot copper pillar.

{@b Atata, The Fourth Court.} If a creature is guilty economic fraud or cheating, it is sent to Atata. King Wuguan judges those sent here to either be bound and continuously pounded by a large stone mallet or be restrained within a large mortar while a massive pestle grinds them.

{@b Hahava, The Fifth Court.} This court is for those that have plotted another's death to obtain their property and for money lenders that charged exorbitant rates. King Yanluo lets transgressors tumble down a never-ending slope of the sharpest blades.

{@b Huhuva, The Sixth Court.} Cheaters and kidnappers are sent here, along with those that objectify others, or waste food. A visit to The Sixth Court entails being slowly sawn into two from groin to head by King Piencheng, only to be glued back together before starting over.

{@b Utpala, The Seventh Court.} Those who have committed psychological abuse or thrived on sowing rumors about others. King Taishan pulls out the tongues of his visitors before trapping them in a wok of boiling oil.
{@b Padma, The Eighth Court.} The Eighth Court is the destination for those that have brought dishonor or shame to their family. King Dushi pulls out their intestines and dismembers their bodies.

{@b Avici, The Ninth Court.} Only the worst of the worst are sent to Avici. Rapists, murderers, and those that had the means to stop such atrocities but didn't are among those found here. While those sentenced to another court are always released at some point, most of the souls trapped here are never released. The court is presided over by King Pingdeng. Each prisoner is dismembered and crushed for all eternity.

{@b Men-Po Pavilion, The Tenth Court.} Those that find themselves in The Tenth Court have either lived a decent life or been thoroughly punished for their crimes. King Zhuanlun presides over this domain but doesn't actually pass any judgment. Instead he offers each newcomer a cup of magical tea the Tea of Forgetfulness. It permanently clears a consciousness of all past memories, and even a wish spell can only restore fractions of those memories. Only Orochi herself can ever truly return all memories that have been lost in this way. A visitor must drink the tea before being capable of entering Youdu. Men-Po Pavilion is full of visitors who refuse to drink the tea for various reasons.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (3/Day)
headerEntries: Ryu can innately cast {@spell control weather}, {@spell divine word}, {@spell tsunami} and {@spell whirlwind|XGE} (spell save {@dc 27}). his spellcasting ability is Charisma.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: Ryu can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Aura of Vitality
entries: Ryu and his allies within 30 feet of him regenerate 10 hit points at the start of each of Ryu's turns.

trait.name: Discorporation
entries: When Ryu drops to 0 hit points or dies, his body is destroyed but his essence travels back to Tengoku, and he is unable to take physical form for a time.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: Ryu is immune to any spell or effect that would alter his form.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Ryu fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Lightning Aura
entries: At the start of each of Ryu's turns, each creature of Ryu's choosing within 10 feet of him takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) lightning damage. A hostile creature that touches Ryu or hits him with a melee attack while within 10 feet of him takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) lightning damage.

trait.name: Limited Magic Immunity
entries: Unless it wishes to be affected, Ryu is immune to spells of
5th level or lower. It has advantage against all other spells and magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: Ryu's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Ryu casts a spell or controls a spell in a way that costs an action. He then makes three attacks: two with his claws and one with his tail.

action.name: Booming Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 25 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d8 + 10}) bludgeoning damage plus 11 ({@damage 2d10}) thunder damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed a {@dc 27} Strength saving throw or be pushed back 20 feet and knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Tempestuous Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}24 ({@damage 4d6 + 10}) slashing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) lightning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed a {@dc 27} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Storm Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: Ryu exhales lightning in a 10 feet wide, 120 feet long line. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 27} Dexterity saving throw, taking 105 ({@damage 30d6}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: Ryu attacks with either his Booming Tail or his Tempestuous Claws.

legendary.name: Cast Spell (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Ryu casts a spell.

legendary.name: Deep Strike (Costs 5 Actions)
entries: In a flash of lightning, Ryu disappears into the stormy skies above him. At the end of the next hostile creature's turn, Ryu smashes into the ground with the force of a gigantic lightning strike. Each creature within 60 feet of the point of impact, must make a {@dc 26} Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 70 ({@damage 20d6}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. The lightning ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: Ryu makes a Wisdom (perception) check.

legendary.name: Sonic Boom (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Ryu supercharges himself with lightning and instantly moves 60 feet in a direction of his choosing as he discharges the energy. Each creature Ryu passes through in that line takes 18 ({@damage 4d8}) thunder damage, and must succeed a {@dc 26} Strength saving throw or become knocked {@condition prone}.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Ryu beats his wings. Each creature within 15 feet of Ryu must succeed a {@dc 27} Dexterity saving throw or take 24 ({@damage 4d6 + 10}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. Ryu can then fly up to half his flying speed.

At the heart of Oriental faith are five spiritual creatures, each guarding a direction on the compass as well as the center. Each Shijin has a corresponding season, color, element, virtue, and other traits which connect them with the daily routines of the mortal races. An earth wu jen, for example, would draw on the domain of Kirin, while a water shugenja would prey to Genbu, and a warlock with a Great Phoenix patron might get her powers from one of the Great Phoenixes or even Suzaku herself.

Genbu, Kirin, Suzaku, and Ryu all have their own holiday in the Orient, where they and their corresponding virtues are celebrated. Noticeably, Orochi doesn't have a holiday, as she is considered at the center of everything.
The Shijin answer to the Jade Emperor alone — the spirit of the First Emperor who united the Clans.

entries.name: Serafs
entries: Over the millennia, the Shijin have created great creatures in their own image. These creatures are almost as revered as the Shijin themselves, as they act as proxies for the Shijin they serve. They are known as the Serafs; guardians of virtue and the circle of life. Orochi is the exception here, as she has not created any creatures in her own image. She has, however, created serpentine creatures to help her rid the Orient of the undead.

entries.name: Ryu
entries: Ryu is also known as The Azure Wyrm, Great Guardian of the West, Aspect of Wind and Wood, Lord of Fall, Master of Storms, and Father of Propriety. Ryu encompasses the ideal that evil should be cleansed through force, so that evil cannot destroy what good has built. He also masters the weather itself, showering the fields with rain and allowing sailing with his winds.
Ryu is a massive dragon, azure in color, with streaks of white lightning moving across his enormous body. His eyes glow with a fiery hot white, and lightning crackles between his claws.

Scripture claims that the Imperial line (and thus the Emperor himself) is descendant from Ryu and the Great Wyrms. Some claim the Emperor is Ryu in human form, though the Emperor has never made such a claim.

entries.name: Immortal Nature
entries: Ryu doesn't require food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Ryu's Lair
entries: Ryu makes his home in the Perennial Monsoon, a layer of Tengoku that contains the very essence of wind and weather. It is an endless sea with violent storms overhead. A typhoon of world-shattering proportions moves through the Perennial Monsoon. This typhoon is the Cleansing Cyclone: Ryu's lair. Ryu's challenge rating is 30 (155,000 XP) if he is encountered in his lair.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Suzaku's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 26}). Suzaku can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Death Throes
entries: If Suzaku dies, violent flames burst forth from her as she turns to a pile of cinders and dust. Any creature within 60 feet of her when she erupts must make a {@dc 25} Dexterity saving throw, taking 55 ({@damage 10d10}) radiant damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one. The explosion ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

trait.name: Discorporation
entries: When Suzaku's remains are destroyed, she can no longer resurrect from them but her essence travels back to Tengoku, and she is unable to take physical form for a time.

trait.name: Divine Initiative
entries: Suzaku always acts on initiative count 20 (losing ties).

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: Suzaku is immune to any spell or effect that would alter her form.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Suzaku fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Limited Magic Immunity
entries: Unless she wishes to be affected, Suzaku is immune to spells of 5th level or lower. She has advantage against all other spells and magical effects.

trait.name: Radiant Armor
entries: Suzaku adds her Charisma modifier to her AC.

trait.name: Undying Flames (3/Day)
entries: While Suzaku is at 0 hit points, roll a {@dice d6} at the end of each of her turns. On a 6, Suzaku's remains begin to swirl in a violent firestorm as she is reborn with half her hit point total. Any creature within 60 feet of her when she is reborn must make a {@dc 25} Dexterity saving throw, taking 55 ({@damage 10d10}) radiant damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one. The explosion ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried. Suzaku cannot resurrect in this manner if her remains are destroyed by being doused with water, or if they are in an area affected by the {@spell hallow} spell.

trait.name: Variable Divine Illumination
entries: Suzaku sheds bright light in a 30 to 120-foot radius and dim light for an additional number of feet equal to the chosen radius. Suzaku can alter the radius as a bonus action. Any undead with a CR of 10 or lower crumbles to dust if they are illuminated by the bright light, and all other undead have disadvantage on saving throws and ability checks while illuminated by the bright light. The light is daylight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Suzaku uses her holy radiance. She then makes three attacks: one with her beak and two with her talons.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}30 ({@damage 4d10 + 8}) slashing damage.

action.name: Radiant Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}24 ({@damage 3d10 + 8}) slashing damage and 18 ({@damage 4d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Heavenly Fires {@recharge}
entries: Suzaku calls down wave of fiery hot air in a 60-foot line that is 15 feet wide, originating at a point of her choosing within 60 feet of her. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 25} Constitution saving throw, taking 110 ({@damage 20d10}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

action.name: Holy Radiance
entries: Each creature of Suzaku's choice that is within 120 feet of Suzaku and can see her must succeed on a {@dc 25} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creatures saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to Suzaku's Holy Radiance for the next 24 hours.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: Suzaku makes an attack with her talons.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: Suzaku makes a Wisdom (perception) check.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Suzaku beats its wings. Each creature within 15 feet of the phoenix must succeed a {@dc 25} Dexterity saving throw or take 43 ({@damage 10d6 + 8}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. Suzaku can then fly up to half her flying speed.

At the heart of Oriental faith are five spiritual creatures, each guarding a direction on the compass as well as the center. Each Shijin has a corresponding season, color, element, virtue, and other traits which connect them with the daily routines of the mortal races. An earth wu jen, for example, would draw on the domain of Kirin, while a water shugenja would prey to Genbu, and a warlock with a Great Phoenix patron might get her powers from one of the Great Phoenixes or even Suzaku herself.

Genbu, Kirin, Suzaku, and Ryu all have their own holiday in the Orient, where they and their corresponding virtues are celebrated. Noticeably, Orochi doesn't have a holiday, as she is considered at the center of everything.
The Shijin answer to the Jade Emperor alone — the spirit of the First Emperor who united the Clans.

entries.name: Serafs
entries: Over the millennia, the Shijin have created great creatures in their own image. These creatures are almost as revered as the Shijin themselves, as they act as proxies for the Shijin they serve. They are known as the Serafs; guardians of virtue and the circle of life. Orochi is the exception here, as she has not created any creatures in her own image. She has, however, created serpentine creatures to help her rid the Orient of the undead.

entries.name: Suzaku
entries: Suzaku is also known as The First Phoenix, Great Guardian of the North, Aspect of Fire, Lady of Summer, Giver of Life, and Mother of Knowledge.

She resembles a mixture between an eagle and a peacock, with radiant, red feathers covering her massive body. While they resemble feathers, they aren't actually material, but rather they are fiery and radiant energies, contained within shapes that resemble feathers. Suzaku leaves a trail of fiery glimmer behind her from her massive tail feathers. She is a gigantic creature, capable of putting fear and respect into any mortal, though her body language is warm and welcoming.
Suzaku and her phoenixes also guard the constellation known as the Red Gate, which is believed to be the physical entrance into Tengoku, the Far Plane the Shijin originate from.

entries.name: Immortal Nature
entries: Suzaku doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Suzaku's Lair
entries: Suzaku's lair is the Radiant Soul: an enormous shimmering sphere of pure radiance, approximately the size of a small moon. There are no landscapes within, nor anything else physical in nature. It consists solely of life energy and is the source of Suzaku's power over life. Whenever Suzaku dies, she is born again within the Radiant Soul.

The Radiant Soul is located at the center of the Fires of Life; Suzaku's layer of Tengoku. This layer is best imagined as walking on the inside of a sphere, the Radiant Soul always looming up in the sky. The ground is a volcanic landscape, though everything is made up of pure energy, resembling flickering flames, rather than matter. Suzaku's challenge rating is 29 (135,000 XP) if she is encountered in her lair.

monster.name: Tegaa Branchling
languages: understands Druidic and Sylvan, but doesn't speak

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the tegaa remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a small bush.

trait.name: Surprise Attack
entries: If the tegaa surprises a creature and hits it with an attack during the first round of combat, the target takes an extra 3 ({@damage 1d6}) damage from the attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tegaa releases its spore cloud if it can. It then makes two clawed vine attacks.

action.name: Clawed Vines
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) slashing damage.

action.name: Constrict
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 11}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the tegaa can't constrict another target.

action.name: Spore Cloud {@recharge}
entries: The tegaa releases a cloud of spores in a 10-foot radius sphere centered on itself. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw against poison or be affected by extreme vertigo. While affected, a creature falls {@condition prone} whenever it moves 5 feet or takes the Dash or Disengage action. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

The tegaa are berry bushes that have been awakened and infused with powerful magics. They are solitary in nature, living in the same area of the same forest for all of their life, hiding among other bushes. As long as it gets a little sun and water, a tegaa is content and doesn't bother with other creatures unless it is attacked or somebody attempts to steal its berries. It will answer the call of a Great Sylvan, however.

entries.name: Tegaa Berries
entries: Magical berries grow on the tegaa, making them very sought after and extremely valuable. While the people of the Orient generally respect the tegaa and leave them alone, there are some who will pay greatly for their berries, as well as bandits and other goons who are willing to hunt the tegaa for monetary gain. This is all black market activity, however, and very much frowned upon. The Chickadee, Phoenix, Rabbit, Wolf, and Wyvern Clans have outright made it illegal within their borders, and in the Wolf lands doing so even carries the death sentence.

entries.name: Giving Back
entries: A tegaa can live to be 30 35 years. During the last weeks of its life, it changes color to stand out among the other bushes and blooms to carry twice as many berries as usually. This is often a signal to others, that it is alright to harvest its berries, as the tegaa will soon no longer need them.

entries.name: Protectors of Children
entries: Although a tegaa doesn't interfere with others, it might do so if a child is threatened near it, even going so far as to sacrifice itself to save the child. A child that is hurt will also be offered one or more berries, depending on its needs.

monster.name: Tegaa
languages: understands Druidic and Sylvan, but doesn't speak

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the tegaa remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a regular bush.

trait.name: Good Luck
entries: The tegaa cannot suffer disadvantage on all ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws.

trait.name: Tegaa Berries
entries: The tegaa has a number of magic berries of different colors as described below. A character can pick a berry from the tegaa with a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity (sleight of hand) check as an action. A berry withers away and loses its magic after a week if removed from the tegaa or if the tegaa is dead. The tegaa can consume two berries itself as a bonus action on each of its turns. It regrows any spent or stolen berries when it finishes a long rest. If the tegaa takes fire damage, all berries are destroyed.

items.name: Blackberries
entries: The tegaa has 2 ({@dice 1d4}) blackberries. If a creature consumes a blackberry, the damage it deals with its melee attacks increases by 1 and the attacks become magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage. If the tegaa consumes a blackberry, for the duration, its damage instead increases by 2 and its reach increases by 10 feet.

items.name: Blueberries
entries: The tegaa has 2 ({@dice 1d4}) blueberries. If a creature consumes a blueberry, roll a {@dice d6}: it is affected by the {@spell polymorph} spell and randomly changes into one of the following creatures as shown in the table below:
If the tegaa consumes a blueberry, it can roll twice and choose which roll to use. The creature that consumes the blueberry must maintain concentration (as if concentrating on a spell).

items.name: Redberries
entries: The tegaa has 3 ({@dice 1d4 + 1}) redberries. If a creature consumes a redberry, it regains 7 ({@dice 2d4 + 2}) hit points. If the tegaa consumes a redberry, it instead regains 14 ({@dice 4d4 + 4}) hit points and if the amount healed is greater than the tegaa's missing hit points, it gains the excess healing as temporary hit points. While the tegaa has temporary hit points that it gained in this manner, it doesn't have vulnerability to fire damage.

items.name: Silverberries
entries: The tegaa has 1 ({@dice 1d4 - 1}) silverberries. If a creature consumes a silverberry, it gains a +1 bonus to all ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws for 1 minute. If the tegaa consumes a silverberry, for the duration, it gains a +3 bonus instead.

items.name: Whiteberries
entries: The tegaa has 1 ({@dice 1d4 - 1}) whiteberries. If a creature consumes a whiteberry, its AC is increased by 1 for 1 minute. If the tegaa consumes a whiteberry, for the duration, its AC instead increases by 2 and it cannot be critically hit.

trait.name: Surprise Attack
entries: If the tegaa surprises a creature and hits it with an attack during the first round of combat, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage from the attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tegaa releases its spore cloud if it can. It then makes two clawed vine attacks.

action.name: Clawed Vines
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Spore Cloud {@recharge 5}
entries: The tegaa releases a cloud of spores in a 30-foot radius sphere centered on itself. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw against poison or be affected by extreme vertigo. While affected, a creature falls {@condition prone} whenever it moves 5 feet or takes the Dash or Disengage action. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

variant.name: Additional Tegaa Berries
entries: At the DMs discretion, some rare or unique tegaa might have additional berries as described below:

items.name: Frostberries
entries: The tegaa has 2 ({@dice 1d4}) frostberries. If a creature consumes a frostberry, it must make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw, having its speed reduced to 5 for 1 minute and taking 14 ({@damage 4d6}) cold damage on a failed save, or half the cold damage on a successful save. If the tegaa consumes a frostberry, it takes no damage and isn't frozen, but the damage of its attacks change to cold for 1 minute and it gains resistance to cold damage.

items.name: Sparkleberries
entries: The tegaa has 2 ({@dice 1d4}) sparkleberries. If a creature consumes a sparkleberry, it is cured of all diseases, curses, and poisons currently affecting it. If the tegaa consumes a sparkleberry, it also gains immunity to disease, curses, and poisons for 1 hour.

The tegaa are berry bushes that have been awakened and infused with powerful magics. They are solitary in nature, living in the same area of the same forest for all of their life, hiding among other bushes. As long as it gets a little sun and water, a tegaa is content and doesn't bother with other creatures unless it is attacked or somebody attempts to steal its berries. It will answer the call of a Great Sylvan, however.

entries.name: Tegaa Berries
entries: Magical berries grow on the tegaa, making them very sought after and extremely valuable. While the people of the Orient generally respect the tegaa and leave them alone, there are some who will pay greatly for their berries, as well as bandits and other goons who are willing to hunt the tegaa for monetary gain. This is all black market activity, however, and very much frowned upon. The Chickadee, Phoenix, Rabbit, Wolf, and Wyvern Clans have outright made it illegal within their borders, and in the Wolf lands doing so even carries the death sentence.

entries.name: Giving Back
entries: A tegaa can live to be 30 35 years. During the last weeks of its life, it changes color to stand out among the other bushes and blooms to carry twice as many berries as usually. This is often a signal to others, that it is alright to harvest its berries, as the tegaa will soon no longer need them.

entries.name: Protectors of Children
entries: Although a tegaa doesn't interfere with others, it might do so if a child is threatened near it, even going so far as to sacrifice itself to save the child. A child that is hurt will also be offered one or more berries, depending on its needs.

trait.name: Ambusher
entries: The wyvern has advantage on attack rolls against any creature it has surprised.

trait.name: Berserk
entries: Whenever the wyvern starts its turn with 50 hit points or fewer, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 6, the wyvern goes berserk. On each of its turns while berserk, the wyvern attacks the nearest creature it can see. If no creature is near enough to move to and attack, the wyvern attacks an object, with preference for an object smaller than itself. Once the wyvern goes berserk, it continues to do so until it is destroyed or regains all its hit points.

trait.name: Underwater Camouflage
entries: The wyvern has advantage on Dexterity (stealth) checks made while underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The wyvern makes three attacks: two with its bite and one with its stinger. While flying or swimming, it can use its claws in place of two other attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Stinger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 15 ft., one creature. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage. The target must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, taking 24 ({@damage 7d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Wyverns are large winged lizards with a stinging tail and sharp teeth. They aren't very intelligent, but they make up for their lack of intelligence with their ferocity. Being very aggressive towards any creature that isn't obviously stronger that itself, and being tenacious in regards to letting prey escape, they are formidable and feared opponents.

entries.name: Oriental Variations
entries: The Orient is home to several varieties of wyvern, though they share some common qualities: They all have two scaly legs, leathery wings, and a sinewy tailed topped with its most potent weapon: its deadly poison stinger.

entries.name: Blue Sea Wyvern
entries: While as aggressive as most other wyverns, the black sea wyvern is also a patient hunter. It prefers to lie in waiting for its prey to come close, rather than to blindly pursue it.

entries.name: Ambushers of the Sea
entries: Always living near the sea, the wyvern will hide beneath the waves, attacking anything smaller than itself. Sea wyverns resemble forest wyvern, though despite their names, sea wyverns are more aquamarine than blue.

entries.name: Forest Wyvern
entries: A forest wyvern's scales vary in color from dark brown to gray, and they are roughly 15 feet in length, with the tail making up half that length. They weigh about a ton.

entries.name: Aerial Hunters
entries: A wyvern doesn't fight on the ground unless it can't reach its prey by any other means, or if it has been fooled into a position from which aerial combat isn't an option. If forced into a confrontation on the ground, a wyvern crouches low, keeping its stinger poised above its head as it hisses and growls.

entries.name: Aggressive and Reckless
entries: A wyvern intent on its prey backs down only if it sustains serious injury, or if its prey eludes it long enough for another easier potential meal to wander along. If it corners a fleeing creature in an enclosure too small to enter, a wyvern guards where the quarry hides, lashing with its stinger whenever opportunity allows. Although they possess more cunning than ordinary beasts, wyverns lack the intelligence of their draconic cousins. As such, creatures that maintain their composure as a wyvern hunts them from the air can often elude or trick it. Wyverns follow a direct path to their prey, with no thought given to possible ambushes.

entries.name: Great Black Mountain Wyvern
entries: This is by far the largest, as well as the most feared and ferocious, of the wyvern. It is twice the size of the forest wyvern, and it can enter mad fits of rage when wounded, disregarding its own health completely. If encountered in its territory, it will attack on sight, even if it stands to lose the fight.

entries.name: Limited Flight
entries: Black mountain wyverns live high in the mountains and are naturally adapted to the cold climates. They are, however, not that good at flying, as their wingspan isn't great enough to support its massive weight. They weigh up to seven tons.

entries.name: Green Mountain Wyvern
entries: Though physically similar to the forest wyvern, albeit a little smaller, this wyvern is the most intelligent and calm of all the wyverns. While still an aggressive creature, it rarely attacks unless hungry or provoked. If raised as a hatchling, they will often bond to only a single person, protecting them with their life.

entries.name: Wyvern Clan Mounts
entries: The Wyvern Clan has both a battalion of samurai that ride these wyverns (being called the Green Blades), as well as a few wu jen (being called the Nodo Skymages).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The wyvern makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its stinger. While flying, it can use its claws in place of one other attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Stinger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage. The target must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, taking 24 ({@damage 7d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Wyverns are large winged lizards with a stinging tail and sharp teeth. They aren't very intelligent, but they make up for their lack of intelligence with their ferocity. entries.name: Green Mountain Wyvern
entries: Though physically similar to the forest wyvern, albeit a little smaller, this wyvern is the most intelligent and calm of all the wyverns. While still an aggressive creature, it rarely attacks unless hungry or provoked. If raised as a hatchling, they will often bond to only a single person, protecting them with their life.

entries.name: Wyvern Clan Mounts
entries: The Wyvern Clan has both a battalion of samurai that ride these wyverns (being called the Green Blades), as well as a few wu jen (being called the Nodo Skymages).

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the wyvern can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

trait.name: Berserk
entries: Whenever the wyvern starts its turn with 80 hit points or fewer, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 5 or 6, the wyvern goes berserk. On each of its turns while berserk, the wyvern attacks the nearest creature it can see. If no creature is near enough to move to and attack, the wyvern attacks an object, with preference for an object smaller than itself. Once the wyvern goes berserk, it continues to do so until it is destroyed or regains all its hit points.

trait.name: Limited Flight
entries: The wyvern can fly for no more than 1 minute before it needs to land and rest for at least 1 minute.

trait.name: Rampage
entries: When the wyvern reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the wyvern can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make a bite attack.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the wyvern takes 20 damage or less that would reduce it to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead. If the wyvern is berserk, it is reduced to 1 hit point even if it takes more than 30 damage.

trait.name: Territorial Predator
entries: While in the area it considers its territory, the wyvern has advantage on attack rolls against creatures that are Large or larger.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The wyvern makes three attacks: two with its bite and one with its stinger. While flying, it can use its claws in place of two other attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 4d6 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}24 ({@damage 4d8 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Stinger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 15 ft., one creature. {@h}20 ({@damage 4d6 + 6}) piercing damage. The target must make a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw, taking 24 ({@damage 7d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Shriek {@recharge 5}
entries: The wyvern emits a high pitched shriek. Each creature within 30 feet of the wyvern must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw, taking 54 ({@damage 12d8}) thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

Wyverns are large winged lizards with a stinging tail and sharp teeth. They aren't very intelligent, but they make up for their lack of intelligence with their ferocity. Being very aggressive towards any creature that isn't obviously stronger that itself, and being tenacious in regards to letting prey escape, they are formidable and feared opponents.
